Many investors showed an interest in South African business on the grounds of their signatures under financial statements of local firms. The “brand” name of the professional and the firm had become entrenched and should not be discarded for limited national concerns. Since jurists of non-South African origin were allowed to practice as lawyers and advocates in South Africa, the same was demanded for non-resident foreign accountants and auditors. If Government wanted to place the accountancy profession in South Africa on a sound uniform statutory basis, foreign professionals (and their firms) ought to be included in professional practice. A modern society allowed free movement of human capital, goods and finance in global markets. Any decision of whether or not to collaborate with foreign professionals should be the prerogative of the profession (Hansard, 1951: 4128–4130; 4136–4137; 4434–4457; 9365–9366). At the committee stage of the third reading of the bill in Parliament, the Minister accepted as a compromise an amendment providing for a five-year window period to allow non-residents to decide on their domicile (Hansard, 1951: 9365–9366). The denial of practising rights to non-residents was not a new restriction implemented by a “nationalist” Government – it was the perpetuation of similar restrictions going back to the 1904 Transvaal Ordinance (TSA, 1906: 11).

sec.title: The Public Accountants’ and Auditors’ Board, the state and the profession
sec.p:
When the PAAB met for the first time on 24 October 1951, the Minister of Finance NC Havenga described the main achievement of the Act not as the “establishment of a closed shop in the profession” or the embedding of “privileges of the newly established monopoly”, but in improving the faith of the public and Parliament in the profession “not to abuse power granted to it, not to fail to perform duties laid down to it … ”, which would “by virtue of the accountancy profession … bring ample reward in the recognition by the public as well as by the Government of the profession’s status and importance”. State intervention was justified on the grounds of the long, drawn-out, seemingly insurmountable differences among accountants in the country (TES, 2258/9/345/2: 24/10/51; PAAB, Minutes 24/10/51). The interventionist state, which characterized the post-Second World War era (Walker and Shackleton, 1995: 475–477; Yergin and Stanislav, 1998: 14–35), became visible in a more explicit acceptance of obligations to citizens and the expression of its responsibility to represent and protect the public interest. The South African state acted in similar fashion in its decision of 1946 to intervene in the drawn-out accountancy professional closure struggle to protect the public interest against inefficient, unprofessional and unqualified accountants and auditors (TES, 2258/9/349/2: 19/2/45; 2258/9/349/2: 3/10/46). This was echoed when the Minister described the most important aspect of the Act as the statutory responsibility of auditors to report “material irregularities” to the PAAB. He said:
To my mind the most important aspect of this piece of legislation is Parliament’s recognition of the principle that an auditor owes a duty not only to his client, but also to the public. For many years auditors have been in doubt as to their responsibility to the public. Parliament has now given a clear and unequivocal answer. I wish in this connection to refer particularly to subsection 3 of section 26. Although it is not claimed that the provision of this subsection will give complete protection to the interest of creditors and local and overseas investors, advantages as yet unforeseen will undoubtedly accrue from the recognition of the principle embodied in that subsection, namely that the auditor should, if his client fails to satisfy him, report material irregularities to the statutory body, the Public Accountants’ and Auditors’ Board. (TES, 2258/9/345/2: 24/10/51; PAAB, Minutes 24/10/51)
The interventionist state linked its responsibility to ordinary citizens to proclaiming the accountability of the accountancy profession to the public at large.

The state was committed to governance of the profession through the PAAB, which was entrusted by Parliament with a “grave responsibility, in the spirit of loyal public service” and “in the best traditions of being our brother’s keeper”. Using the statutory mechanism, the Minister called on the profession to consolidate the achievements of the Act by taking the “necessary steps considered expedient for the maintenance of the integrity, the enhancement of the status and the improvement of the integrity of professional qualifications of accountants and auditors” (PAAB, Minutes 24/10/51). This was a conciliatory speech. The composition of the first PAAB reflected the same inclusivity. The PAAB consisted of the following members: Mr JM Wells as representative of the Commissioner of Inland Revenue; Mr JJ Adams as Registrar of Companies, Mr VG Chowles as representative of the Department of Trade and Industry; Professor WFJ Steenkamp from the Board of Trade and Industries; Professors BJS Wimble and PW Hoek representing the universities; Mr K Lamont Smith (TSA), A Dickson (TSA), LE Carter (CSA), AL Sargeant (SA branch Society of Incorporated Accountants), GE Noyce (NSA), CD Ramsden and AS Leith (SAAOFS), Mr N Glen, FD Kydd Coutts, RS Clark and M Honickman (SA branch of APA). The meeting elected Mr K Lamont Smith as chairman of the first PAAB and the first executive committee members elected were Mr JJ Wells, Prof BJS Wimble and Messrs E Carter and GE Noyce as representative of the Societies, and Messrs N Glen and M Honickman representing the other accounting organizations. The influential position of the Societies was noteworthy.

sec.title: Conclusion: Joint state–profession closure strategy
sec.p: The accountancy profession succeeded with a closure strategy similar to closure strategies in the UK and other parts of the Commonwealth. The only difference was that the state intervened proactively by introducing a public act and established a statutory body, with more non-accountants than accountants, to execute statutory regulation of the profession – from registration, to examination, to licensing. Efforts of the accountancy profession in a settler society to create a new identity and context for development compared with that of the medical profession and the legal fraternity. All the professional initiatives in the former colonies, and later in the Union of South Africa, were path-dependent on the professional developments in the countries of origin, especially Britain (Johnson and Caygill, 1971; Poullaos, 2009: 247–259; SC, 12/38: 13). The battles of professional “closure” in Britain played themselves out in South Africa, but this continuity of experiences with the rest of the imperial accountancy arena developed a unique direction in South Africa. While the theory on the state–profession nexus has identified varying degrees of symbiosis or mutual dependency between the emerging accountancy profession and the modern state (Torstendahl and Burrage, 1990), many studies have alluded to the appeals to the state to support or facilitate professional closure strategies (Chua and Poullaos, 1993; Chua and Sinclair, 199; Miller, 1990; Poullaos, 1993; Richardson 1989; Walker and Shackleton, 1995; Willmott, 1986). The Societies of Chartered Accountants’ initial closure attempts failed, since at least five other associations of accountants contested their exclusive position. In the Weberian sense the Chartered Societies’ attempts to secure the subordination of other accountants groups in the Union in order to monopolize advantages by professional closure were frustrated by the growing public opposition to their private legislative efforts. The state first only entered the discourse reluctantly as mediator. The 1927 Designation Act secured the “Chartered” Societies exclusive use of the title CA(SA), but did not prevent other accountants from practising in the Cape or Free State. When the marginalized accountants’ organizations took agency of their interest and challenged the Societies by initiating opposing private bills in Parliament, the Societies had to change their strategy. As pointed out in the work of Chua and Poullaos (1993), Lee (1990a, 1990b) and Macdonald (1985), attempts by accountants at different times and localities to secure professional closure often enlisted the support of the state to arrive at their ultimate goal. Collins describes this process as a dynamic one (Chua and Poullaos, 1993: 694; Collins, 1990a: 23). In South Africa the state changed its reluctance to proactive intervention, whereby it engineered, in the Parkin sense of a legal monopoly over the provision of a service, much earlier closure, more inclusive closure, and greater non-accountants’ agency in the regulation of the profession, than elsewhere in the imperial accountancy arena. This was the first time in the Commonwealth that the state and the accountancy profession jointly arrived (albeit as a result of state inducement) at “adequate professional closure” of inclusive statutory regulation of the profession on the basis of collaboration (through non-accountant civil servants) in a single national regulatory body. It is an open debate whether such state control of the profession was better, more efficient or preferable to other closure mechanisms in other Commonwealth countries. That is a topic for future investigation.

This article brings a new dimension to the histories of closure strategies by showing how the failure of professional closure, in the Weberian sense of enclosing public practice opportunities, by the accountancy profession in South Africa, later intersected with the state’s emerging role as caretaker of the public interest. The intervention of the state was not an authoritarian attempt to regulate the accountancy profession from above, but to facilitate intra-profession collaboration, constantly seeking simultaneous consensus within the profession and between the profession and the state. This case study of South Africa shows how a proactive state facilitated professional closure and state regulation in collaboration with the profession. The accountancy profession in South Africa achieved the most comprehensive professional unity to date in 1951, but the opportunity cost was an end to self-regulation and the sanctioning of state regulation.

The promulgation of the PAA Act in 1951 introduced interventionist statutory regulation of a comprehensive nature to the profession on a unitary national basis. The South African experience in the Commonwealth, or the imperial accountancy arena, afforded non-accountants and representatives of the accountancy profession jointly a statutory regulatory function. The obligation to report material irregularities to a statutory body was unprecedented in the Commonwealth. Elsewhere in the Commonwealth, state regulation of the accountancy profession occurred in different ways. The New Zealand Society of Accountants Act, 1908 afforded statutory status to the New Zealand Society of Accountants, granting “registered accountant” status to numerous commercial accountants and bookkeepers. The aim of the Act was to afford the Society the right to control and regulate the practice of the profession of accountancy in New Zealand. This was not a state body. In principle this act can be compared to Ordinance No. 3 (Private) of 1904 in the SAR, where the accountants’ organization was granted statutory recognition and afforded certain professional regulatory powers. Non-members of the New Zealand Society were not prevented from referring to themselves as “accountants”. The Minister for Internal Affairs refused the New Zealand Society of Accountants’ request to make it an offence for anyone to use the title “accountant” who was not a member of the Society (South African Accountant and Auditor, 1908: 110). This did not result in a single statutory body in which all accounting organizations in New Zealand were represented under state control, but afforded the New Zealand Society statutory status. In Ceylon an accountancy board was set up under the Companies (Auditors) Regulations 1941. This body consisted predominantly of government nominees and required the registration of accountants for the purpose of the audit of companies (Yapa, 2010: 127–128). The British Colonial Administration regulated audit practitioners. This board was not intended to bring about professional unity or regulate all aspects of the accountancy profession. It was an auditing governance mechanism of the British Colonial Administration. In India the Indian Accountancy Board was also established by the British Colonial Administration in 1932 under the Company Law Amendment Bill, to advise the Governor-General on the regulation of the accountancy profession in India. After India’s independence in 1948 the Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI) was established in 1949 (Verma, 2010: 193–201). The IAB and later the ICAI had similar functions to the PAAB in South Africa. The difference in these contexts was that the state had initiated and controlled the regulatory bodies in Ceylon and India, while the profession in New Zealand and South Africa attempted to exert professional closure in the Weberian sense from a professional self-regulation stance. In South Africa the TSA had some success in the SAR, and the NSA in Natal before 1910. A legal monopoly affording professional closure in the way Parkin explained it only materialized in 1951 in South Africa. It did not happen in New Zealand in 1908, but was implemented by the British Colonial Administrations in Ceylon and India from 1941 and 1932 respectively. However, the State did not intervene in New Zealand, Ceylon or India to bring about professional closure through professional collaboration, at the same time as nationwide exclusive regulation of accounting practice was introduced, as had been done in South Africa.

The accountancy profession in South Africa was not left at the mercy of an all-powerful state, but retained a strong voice on the PAAB from where, as will be shown in later research, it carved out a controlling position in future professional matters (Verhoef, 2011). How the state–profession nexus developed after 1951 is to be the subject of another article.

In the four British colonies which formed the constitutional Union of South Africa in 1910, separate professional organizations of accountants were formed. The first was the Transvaal Society of Accountants (TSA), incorporated into the Transvaal Colony by means of Ordinance No. 3 (Private) of 1904. Similar accountants’ organizations were formed in the Cape Colony in 1908, in the Orange River Colony in 1907 and in the Natal Colony in 1909 (the Accountants’ Act, No. 35 of 1909, Natal).

Chua and Poullaos admit “Our access to South African material was restricted to material collected in Britain. While it provides evidence of positions transmitted to the Colonial Office and the ICAEW, it is insufficient to capture the nuances of the complex South African arena” (2002: 415). Poullaos refers to the South African case as “South African and the imperial accountancy arena” (2009: 258), and again in 2010 Poullaos contributed an entire chapter on “The self-governing Dominions of South Africa, Australia, Canada …” without reference to primary source material from the South African archives (Poullaos, 2010). The intention of the authors was, however, not to analyse the South African professionalization process, but as stated on p. 11, to highlight cross-border engagements without seeking “to comprehensively capture the internal professional dynamics in Britain, Canada, Australia and South Africa. That is … not [to] provide a history of professionalization in those locales”.

Although the authors Chua and Poullaos caution against interpreting “closure” in an undifferentiated manner (Chua and Poullaos, 1993: 693–694; Chua and Poullaos, 1998: 156), the closure strategies in Australia were differentiated and aimed at different closure mechanisms.

Strictly speaking, a person could practice as an accountant in the Cape or the Orange Free State without being a member of the accountancy societies.
